text: this is Randy Archibald with the New
York Times reporting from Los Angeles
right now in California there are eight
wildfires burning of various size and
destruction the largest is called the
station fire in it's burning about 20
miles north of downtown Los Angeles in
the foothills of the San Gabriel
Mountains it's about a hundred and
twenty-two thousand acres roughly the
size of two boroughs in New York City
Queens and the Bronx combined that fires
now only five percent contained at well
over a hundred and twenty thousand acres
that fire is growing by the moment we're
very very concerned about that fire
which claimed the lives of two of Fire
Service employees on Sunday this fire is
a little unusual in the realm of
Southern California big catastrophic
fires normally those fires are driven by
stiff hot winds called the Santa Ana
winds that can reach gale or hurricane
force and really produce a firestorm
this fire is not being driven by winds
but rather by heat and extremely dry
brush land the heat was at record levels
over the weekend above a hundred degrees
in many areas the drought has caused a
lot of vegetation to really dry out and
it's also in really steep craggy terrain
so all those factors combined have made
this a truly unusual difficult fire it's
spreading in many different directions
usually they spread in one direction
driven by the winds again but this time
it's it's really on many fronts the
cause of the fire is not determined at
this point usually what happens is once
the fire is a little bit more under
control investigators can get in and see
where the fire started and if there are
clues as to its origins
the California economy has been
struggling in the past year or so but
the governor and his people have tried
to give assurances that there will be
money to fight these fires and any fires
that come up in the coming peak of the
fire season which is usually September
in October it's important for everyone
to know that we have the money available
to fight those files so many how many
files we have we have the money
available but you also should understand
that it is very important for us to go
and to pass the emergency response
initiative which I've been fighting for
because it will give us extra more than
a hundred million dollars in fighting
those files the weather seems to have
taken a turn for the better the
temperatures have come down that
humidity is going up those are all good
things for the firefighting effort still
this fire is so massive that
firefighters do not expect to have it
surrounded or close to being put out for
another two weeks they've given a date
of September 15th as a target but it
really depends on the weather continuing
to improve
